wikipedia_page.main:
James William Montgomery Bradshaw (23 November 1906 – 5 December 1938) was an English cricketer. Bradshaw was a left-handed batsman who was a right-arm bowler, although his bowling style is unknown. He was born in Oakham, Rutland.
He made his first-class debut for Leicestershire against Sir J Cahn's XI in 1935. He made 2 further first-class appearances, against Sir L Parkinson's XI in 1935 and Oxford University in 1938.  In his 3 matches, he scored 95 runs at an average of 31.66, with a high score of 82. This score came in his debut match against Sir J Cahn's XI.  He also took a single wicket, that of Oxford University batsman John Guy.His cousins, James Bradshaw and Walter Bradshaw, both played first-class cricket for Leicestershire. Bradshaw died in the town of his birth on 5 December 1938.

* James Bradshaw (cricketer, born 1906) (1906–1938), English cricketer, played for Leicestershire 1935–38
* James Bradshaw (minister) (1636–1702), English clergyman and ejected minister
* James Bradshaw (MP) (1786–1847), Member of Parliament for Brackley, Berwick-upon-Tweed, 1835–1837, and Canterbury, 1837–1847
* James Bradshaw of The British Family, family avoiding imported goods in 2013
* Albert James Bradshaw (1882–1956), Canadian politician, businessman and farmer
